questions.text: Structure injured in submandibular gland excision:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

During a submandibular gland excision, the lingual nerve is one of the most vulnerable structures. The submandibular gland lies in the submandibular triangle, and the lingual nerve runs in close proximity to the gland, specifically looping inferiorly below the submandibular duct (Wharton's duct) and then ascending to supply sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and providing parasympathetic innervation for the sublingual gland. Due to its anatomical course, which brings it very close to the superior aspect of the submandibular gland and duct, it is at significant risk of injury (e.g., stretching, compression, or transection) during dissection, especially when ligating or dividing the submandibular duct. Injury to the lingual nerve can lead to loss of taste sensation and general sensation over the anterior two-thirds of the tongue on the affected side.

questions.text: Patient is brought to emergency after road traffic accident with multiple fractures of humerus. On examination he is unable to flex and supinate forearm. Also there is loss of sensations on lateral aspect of forearm. Which of the following Nerve is injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6, C7) innervates the major muscles responsible for forearm flexion and supination, and it also provides sensory innervation to the lateral forearm.

  • Motor Function:

    • It supplies the biceps brachii (strong flexor and supinator of the forearm).
    • It supplies the brachialis (major flexor of the forearm).
    • It supplies the coracobrachialis (flexor of the arm at the shoulder).
    • Therefore, an injury to the musculocutaneous nerve would result in the inability to flex and supinate the forearm.

  • Sensory Function:

    • After innervating the forearm muscles, the musculocutaneous nerve continues as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm. This nerve provides sensation to the lateral aspect of the forearm.
    • Thus, loss of sensation on the lateral aspect of the forearm is a classic sign of musculocutaneous nerve injury.

Given the combination of motor deficits (inability to flex and supinate forearm) and sensory loss (lateral forearm), the musculocutaneous nerve is the only nerve that accounts for all these symptoms. Humerus fractures, particularly in the distal part or supracondylar region, can sometimes involve injury to this nerve, although it's less common than radial nerve injury in mid-shaft fractures.

questions.text: Downward enlargement of spleen prevented by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The phrenicocolic ligament (also known as the sustentaculum lienis) is a peritoneal fold that extends from the splenic flexure of the colon to the diaphragm at the level of the eleventh rib. It forms a shelf-like structure upon which the inferior pole of the spleen rests. This ligament acts as a crucial support, preventing the spleen from displacing downwards or prolapsing into the lower abdomen, especially when enlarged (splenomegaly). Its anatomical position directly inferior to the spleen provides a physical barrier against its downward descent.

questions.text: Nerve damaged when shunt is placed using great saphenous vein ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The saphenous nerve is a sensory branch of the femoral nerve. It accompanies the great saphenous vein for a significant portion of its course in the leg and ankle. In the thigh, it travels with the femoral artery and vein in the adductor canal. In the leg, it emerges from the adductor canal and descends alongside the great saphenous vein, passing anterior to the medial malleolus at the ankle. Due to this close anatomical relationship, especially when the great saphenous vein is harvested or dissected for use in bypass grafts (e.g., coronary artery bypass grafts, peripheral bypass grafts) or when central venous access is gained through the saphenous vein, the saphenous nerve is highly vulnerable to injury. Damage to the saphenous nerve can result in numbness, paresthesia, or pain along the medial aspect of the leg and foot, which is its area of sensory distribution.

questions.text: A patient presented with the extension of the MCP joint and flexion of IP. Which muscle is affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The patient's presentation describes a specific hand deformity: extension of the Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and flexion of the Interphalangeal (IP) joints. This is characteristic of a "claw hand" deformity.

The correct answer is C. Interossei and lumbricals.

Explanation for the Correct Answer (C):

The interossei and lumbrical muscles are the intrinsic muscles of the hand that play a crucial role in the precise movements of the fingers. Their primary actions are:

  • Flexion of the MCP joints.
  • Extension of the IP joints (proximal and distal).

When these muscles are weakened or paralyzed (e.g., due to ulnar nerve injury which supplies most interossei and medial two lumbricals, or median nerve injury for lateral two lumbricals), their opposing muscles, the long extensors (extensor digitorum) and long flexors (flexor digitorum superficialis and profundus), become unopposed.

The unopposed action leads to:

  • Extension of the MCP joints: The long extensors pull the MCP joints into hyperextension.
  • Flexion of the IP joints: The long flexors pull the IP joints into flexion.

This specific combination of MCP extension and IP flexion is the classic "claw hand" deformity, which is a hallmark sign of dysfunction of the interossei and lumbricals.

questions.text: Aneurysm of which artery causes visual defects by compressing at optic chiasma ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The anterior communicating artery (AComA) is a short vessel that connects the two anterior cerebral arteries (ACAs) across the midline, forming a crucial part of the Circle of Willis. It lies in extremely close anatomical proximity, directly superior and often anterior, to the optic chiasm. The optic chiasm is where nerve fibers from the medial (nasal) halves of both retinas cross over, while fibers from the lateral (temporal) halves continue uncrossed.

Therefore, an aneurysm arising from the AComA, when it enlarges, can exert direct compressive force on the optic chiasm. This compression specifically damages the crossing fibers, leading to a classic visual field defect known as bitemporal hemianopia (loss of vision in the outer half of both visual fields). This makes AComA aneurysms a significant cause of visual defects due to chiasmal compression.

questions.text: The following cell is inhibitory to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The Purkinje cells are the sole output neurons of the cerebellar cortex. They are unique in that they are GABAergic, meaning they release the neurotransmitter GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid), which is an inhibitory neurotransmitter. The axons of Purkinje cells project almost exclusively to the deep cerebellar nuclei (dentate, emboliform, globose, and fastigial nuclei) and, to a lesser extent, directly to the vestibular nuclei.

Therefore, the Purkinje cells exert an inhibitory influence on the neurons within the deep cerebellar nuclei. This inhibition is crucial for the cerebellum to modulate and fine-tune motor control, coordination, and learning. The deep cerebellar nuclei, in turn, send excitatory projections out of the cerebellum to various brain regions involved in motor control.

questions.text: Identify the Pelvic diaphragm in the below pic given picture
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The pelvic diaphragm is correctly labeled as C in the diagram. It is a muscular structure composed primarily of the levator ani and coccygeus muscles, forming the floor of the pelvic cavity. Its key roles include supporting the pelvic organs, maintaining continence, and assisting in childbirth by resisting intra-abdominal pressure. In the diagram, label C represents a muscle structure forming a sling-like floor, which is characteristic of the pelvic diaphragm. It separates the pelvic cavity above from the perineal region below, and its anatomical position and muscular texture confirm its identification.

questions.text: Which of the following structures in the scapula is palpable in the infraclavicularfossa?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The structure labeled C is the coracoid process, which is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa. It is a small, hook-like bony projection from the anterior surface of the scapula, lying just below the clavicle (in the infraclavicular area). Clinically, the coracoid process serves as an important landmark for procedures such as brachial plexus blocks and is also a site of attachment for several muscles and ligaments including the pectoralis minor, coracobrachialis, and the short head of the biceps brachii. Due to its anterior and superficial position, it can be easily palpated just medial to the shoulder joint beneath the clavicle.

questions.text: A Patient presented with the deformity as shown in pic. Which of the following nerves are involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The hand deformity in the image is a classic example of "ulnar claw hand", which occurs due to ulnar nerve injury. This deformity is characterized by hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and flexion at the proximal and distal interphalangeal (PIP and DIP) joints, most prominently in the ring and little fingers. This occurs because the ulnar nerve innervates the medial two lumbricals and interossei muscles, which normally flex the MCP and extend the IP joints. When the ulnar nerve is damaged, these muscles become non-functional, and the unopposed action of the extensor digitorum and long finger flexors causes the characteristic claw-like posture.

choices.text: Right Gastric and Right gastroepiploic artery
Right Gastric and Left gastric artery
Right Gastroepiploic and Left short gastric vessels
Right Gastric and short gastric vessels

questions.text: Ligation of the common hepatic artery will impair blood supply in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The common hepatic artery is a major branch of the celiac trunk, and it gives rise to several important vessels supplying the liver, stomach, duodenum, and pancreas. Two key branches of the common hepatic artery are the right gastric artery (usually a direct branch of the proper hepatic artery) and the gastroduodenal artery, which in turn gives off the right gastroepiploic artery. Therefore, ligation of the common hepatic artery would cut off the direct supply to both the right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries, severely impairing blood flow to the lesser and greater curvatures of the stomach on the right side.

questions.text: Structures injured while resecting the free edge of lesser omentum are all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The hepatic vein is the correct answer because it is not located within the free edge of the lesser omentum and therefore is not at risk of injury during its resection. The hepatic veins are found within the liver parenchyma, draining blood from the liver into the inferior vena cava. They lie posteriorly and are not part of the portal triad that runs through the hepatoduodenal ligament, which forms the free edge of the lesser omentum. As a result, hepatic veins are anatomically distant from the structures encountered during lesser omentum resection.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a boundary of calotâ€™striangle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The gall bladder is not a boundary of Calot’s triangle. Calot’s triangle, also known as the cystohepatic triangle, is an important anatomical region in hepatobiliary surgery, particularly during cholecystectomy. Its classical anatomical boundaries include:

  • Medially: Common hepatic duct

  • Inferiorly: Cystic duct

  • Superiorly: Originally the cystic artery (in Calot’s original definition), though in modern surgical anatomy, the superior border is often considered to be the inferior surface of the liver.

The gall bladder lies adjacent to this triangle but does not form one of its borders, which makes Option D the correct answer.

questions.text: Anal canal NOT supplied by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The middle rectal artery primarily supplies the middle portion of the rectum, and not the anal canal specifically. While it can contribute minor anastomotic branches that reach the anal canal, it is not a primary or consistent source of direct blood supply to the anal canal. The anal canal receives its main arterial supply from three key arteries:

  1. Superior rectal artery – a continuation of the inferior mesenteric artery; supplies the upper part of the anal canal above the pectinate line.

  2. Inferior rectal artery – a branch of the internal pudendal artery; supplies the lower part of the anal canal below the pectinate line.

  3. Median sacral artery – a branch from the posterior aspect of the abdominal aorta; contributes to the posterior and lower rectum and anal canal via small branches.

Thus, the middle rectal artery, though important for the rectum, is not considered a significant supplier of the anal canal, making Option D the correct answer.

questions.text: A55-year old man comes to the physician because of swelling in his groin that he first noticed 2 weeks ago Physicale xaminations hows a bulge above the inguinal ligament that increases in size when the patient is asked to cough.He is referred to a surgeon and scheduled to undergo elective laparoscopic hernia repair. Which of the following landmarks will best aid the surgeon in distinguishing an indirect from a direct inguinal hernia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The inferior epigastric vessels are the key anatomical landmark used to differentiate between indirect and direct inguinal hernias. During laparoscopic or open hernia repair, surgeons assess the location of the hernia sac relative to these vessels:

  • An indirect inguinal hernia protrudes lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels and follows the path of the inguinal canal, often originating at the deep inguinal ring.

  • A direct inguinal hernia protrudes medial to the inferior epigastric vessels, through a weakened area in the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, within Hesselbach’s triangle.

Thus, identifying the position of the hernia sac in relation to these vessels allows accurate classification and guides the surgical approach.

choices.text: Attached to spinus process of lumbar vertebra
Attached to transverse process of lumbar vertebra
The fascia lies only posterior to posterior abdominal wall muscles
Gives attachment to Transverse abdominal and internal oblique

questions.text: All are true about Thoracolumbar facia EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
This statement is incorrect, making it the correct answer for an “EXCEPT” question. The thoracolumbar fascia is not limited to lying only posterior to the posterior abdominal wall muscles. Rather, it is a complex trilaminar structure in the lumbar region, consisting of anterior, middle, and posterior layers. These layers envelop muscles like the quadratus lumborum and erector spinae, and serve as attachment sites for muscles of the abdominal wall. The middle and anterior layers are located anterior and posterior to quadratus lumborum, showing that the fascia surrounds—not just lies behind—the muscles. Thus, Option C is false, making it the correct choice for an exception.

questions.text: Stellate cells in liver seen where?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hepatic stellate cells (also known as Ito cells) are found in the Space of Disse, which is the perisinusoidal space between the sinusoidal endothelium and the hepatocytes in the liver. These cells play a critical role in vitamin A storage, extracellular matrix production, and are central in the pathogenesis of liver fibrosis. In their quiescent state, stellate cells store vitamin A in lipid droplets. Upon liver injury, they become activated and transform into myofibroblast-like cells, producing collagen and contributing to fibrosis. Their strategic location in the Space of Disse enables them to interact closely with both blood components and hepatocytes

questions.text: Neurotransmitter secreted by the marked area is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The marked area in the image corresponds to a region of the brain where dopamine is secreted. This is likely the substantia nigra, a part of the midbrain that is known for its role in producing dopamine, a critical neurotransmitter involved in regulating movement, motivation, and reward pathways. Dopamine dysfunction in this area is linked to diseases such as Parkinson's disease, which is characterized by motor control issues due to the loss of dopaminergic neurons. Hence

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of Carotid sheath?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The carotid sheath is a fibrous connective tissue investment in the neck that surrounds the major neurovascular structures. Its primary contents are:

  • The common carotid artery (in the lower neck), which then bifurcates into the internal and external carotid arteries. The internal carotid artery (in the upper neck).
  • The internal jugular vein.
  • The vagus nerve (X cranial nerve).

The sympathetic chain (also known as the sympathetic trunk) is a paired chain of ganglia that runs vertically along the neck, chest, and abdomen. In the neck, it lies posterior to the carotid sheath, resting on the prevertebral fascia. It is not contained within the carotid sheath itself.

questions.text: Branches from Lumber plexus are all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The lumbar plexus is a network of nerves formed in the lumbar region of the spine (L1-L4, and sometimes a contribution from T12). Its major branches supply the anterior and medial thigh, the abdominal wall, and parts of the external genitalia. The sciatic nerve, on the other hand, is the largest nerve in the body and arises from the sacral plexus (L4-S3). It supplies the posterior thigh and all of the leg and foot. Therefore, the sciatic nerve is not a branch of the lumbar plexus.

questions.text: Atrophy of intrinsic muscles of hand, sensory deficit on medial side offorearm and hand, and diminished radial pulse on turning the head on the affected side could be because of :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

A cervical rib is an extra rib arising from the seventh cervical vertebra. Its presence can compress the lower trunk of the brachial plexus and the subclavian artery as they pass over the first rib. This compression leads to a combination of neurological and vascular symptoms. The atrophy of intrinsic muscles of the hand and sensory deficit on the medial side of the forearm and hand occur due to involvement of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (C8-T1 nerve roots), which supplies these muscles and skin areas. The diminished radial pulse on turning the head (Adson’s test positive) is caused by compression of the subclavian artery by the cervical rib, leading to vascular compromise. This cluster of signs and symptoms is characteristic of thoracic outlet syndrome caused by a cervical rib.

questions.text: A 54-year-old alcoholic drinks a large amount of alcohol. After an unknown period of time he is found by his neighbor and brought to the emergency room. The patient eventually arouses but is troubled by a persistent right foot drop. Prolonged compression of what nerve most likely accounts for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

In an alcoholic patient found unconscious or immobile for a prolonged period, the most common cause of a persistent foot drop is compression injury to the common peroneal nerve. This nerve wraps around the neck of the fibula, a superficial location where it is vulnerable to external pressure, especially during prolonged immobility (e.g., lying on a hard surface). Compression leads to weakness of the muscles responsible for dorsiflexion and eversion of the foot, resulting in foot drop. Sensory loss typically affects the lateral aspect of the leg and dorsum of the foot. The common peroneal nerve is therefore the most likely nerve involved in this scenario.

questions.text: Stab straight into the middle of the sternum at the level of 4th coastal cartilage. which wall/ chamber of heart is involved
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A stab wound directed straight into the middle of the sternum at the level of the 4th costal cartilage is most likely to penetrate the right ventricle of the heart. This is because the right ventricle forms the largest and most anterior part of the heart, lying just behind the sternum. At the level of the 4th costal cartilage, the right ventricle is the chamber closest to the sternum, making it the most vulnerable to a direct anterior penetrating injury.

questions.text: Lesion of which of the following will lead to paradoxical respiration
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The structure labeled A corresponds to the phrenic nerve. The phrenic nerve innervates the diaphragm, which is the primary muscle of respiration. A lesion of the phrenic nerve causes paralysis of the diaphragm on the affected side, leading to paradoxical respiration — where the affected side of the diaphragm moves upward during inspiration instead of downward, due to negative intrathoracic pressure pulling the paralyzed diaphragm inward. This abnormal movement impairs effective breathing.

questions.text: Identify the type of fibre marked in the image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The image clearly illustrates projection fibers. These are bundles of nerve fibers that connect the cerebral cortex to subcortical nuclei (like the thalamus, basal ganglia), the brainstem, and the spinal cord. They transmit information both ways: ascending sensory information travels from the body to the cortex, and descending motor commands travel from the cortex to motor centers. The broad, vertical orientation of the marked tract, spanning between the cortex and what would be lower brain regions, is characteristic of major projection pathways such as those forming the internal capsule.
